title: Hal Anderson (baseball)
text:
Harold Anderson (February 10, 1904 – May 1, 1974) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a>, <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a>, and <a href="scout%20%28sports%29">scout</a>. He appeared in nine <a href="games%20played">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> as a <a href="center%20fielder">center fielder</a> for the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a>, but was a longtime star in the <a href="American%20Association%20%2820th%20century%29">American Association</a> and a manager of <a href="farm%20system">farm teams</a> in the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>' organization.
Born in <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>, Anderson threw and batted right-handed and was listed as tall and . He entered baseball in 1922 and by 1926 he was a regular outfielder for the <a href="St.%20Paul%20Saints%20%281901%E2%80%931960%29">St. Paul Saints</a> of the American Association, one of the three top-level <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor leagues</a> of the era. Anderson was not known for his power at the plate, but consistently reached double figures in <a href="stolen%20bases">stolen bases</a> and <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> over .295 for the next six years. His tenure with the Saints culminated with the 1931 season, during which he batted .314 and set personal bests in <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> (23) and <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a> (95). 
The performance led the White Sox to acquire his contract and use Anderson as their starting center fielder for their first eight games of the 1932 <a href="American%20League">American League</a> season. He broke in on April 12 with two <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> in five <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> and two <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>, then, six days later, he had a three-hit game. But all his hits were <a href="single%20%28baseball%29">singles</a> and he stole no bases. With Anderson only eight-for-32 (.250), he lost his starting job to <a href="Liz%20Funk">Elias "Liz" Funk</a> and appeared in only one more MLB game, on April 24 as a defensive replacement. 
The White Sox sent him back to the minors, where he played through 1939. However, in July 1932, the Cardinals purchased Anderson's contract and assigned him to the <a href="Columbus%20Red%20Birds">Columbus Red Birds</a> of the American Association, where he played through 1936 and later returned as Columbus' manager from 1947–1949. Anderson spent more than two decades with the Cardinals as a scout and minor-league skipper.
